question.instruction: Match the examples with the most appropriate Universal Design principle.

options.text: Sidewalks that are wheelchair accessible and have curb cuts that orient people who are blind, assist people with motor disabilities and people who walk with objects such as carts and strollers -> Principle 1, Equitable Use
Detectable warnings built into curb cuts that warn people who are blind that they are approaching a street -> Principle 4, Perceptible Information
Sidewalks that are smooth and absent of bumps and cracks -> Principle 6, Low Physical Effort
Width of sidewalk allows for use of assistive technologies (e.g., rollators, wheelchairs) -> Principle 7, Size and Space for Approach and Use

question.instruction: Match the examples with the most appropriate Universal Design principle.

options.text: Same entrance to the building for all people (instead of a main entrance for people who can walk up stairs and a separate entrance for people in wheelchairs) -> Principle 1, Equitable Use
Buttons on elevators that are tactile or have Braille on them -> Principle 4, Perceptible Information
Doors that have lever handles that require less effort to operate -> Principle 6, Low Physical Effort
Bathrooms that provide sufficient space for maneuverability of body and assistive technologies -> Principle 7, Size and Space for Approach and Use

source: Source: Deque University > IAAP CPACC Certification Preparation> Universal Design for the Physical World (Different Sections)

question.instruction: Match the examples with the most appropriate Universal Design principle.

options.text: Drinking fountains that are placed at varying heights to accommodate different users -> Principle 2, Flexibility in Use
Drinking fountains that have auto-detecting features -> Principle 6, Low Physical Effort
Both audible and visual arrival announcements at train stations -> Principle 4, Perceptible Information
Turnstiles and gates that are large enough and wide enough for wheelchairs and various people to use -> Principle 7, Size and Space for Approach and Use

source: Source: Deque University > IAAP CPACC Certification Preparation> Universal Design for the Physical World (Different Sections)

question.instruction: Match the examples with the most appropriate Universal Design principle.

options.text: Transportation systems that allow mobile devices to provide alerts regarding information and announcements -> Principle 4, Perceptible Information
Taxis that have wheelchair access -> Principle 2, Flexibility in Use

Touchscreens that have larger clickable areas and fonts help prevent people who are visually impaired or have motor disabilities from making mistakes, communicate mistakes, and help users recover from those mistakes -> Principle 5, Tolerance for Error
Emergency exit routes that are accessible and usable for all people -> Principle 1, Equitable Use

source: Source: Deque University > IAAP CPACC Certification Preparation> Universal Design for the Physical World (Different Sections)

question.instruction: Match the examples with the most appropriate Universal Design principle.

options.text: Smoke detectors and other alarm systems that have flashing lights and audio sounds -> Principle 4, Perceptible Information
In grocery store, shelves, product markers, product information, and prices that can be exposed to portable devices -> Principle 1, Equitable Use
In grocery stores, helves placed at lower heights to accommodate diverse needs of shoppers -> Principle 2, Flexibility in Use

For self check-in/checkout systems, having larger clickable areas and fonts help prevent users who are visually impaired or have motor disabilities from making mistakes and recover -> Principle 5, Tolerance for Error

source: Source: Deque University > IAAP CPACC Certification Preparation> Universal Design for the Physical World (Different Sections)

question.instruction: Match the examples with the most appropriate Universal Design principle.

  • WCAG Success Criterion 1.4.11 Non-text Contrast

question.instruction: Under WCAG 2.1, which of the following would violate conformance level A or AA success criteria?

options.text: A bar graph with two colors where contrast ratio between them is 3:1, and where being able to distinguish between those two colors is essential to understanding the content
A form field where color cues and the required attribute are relied upon to indicate which fields must be filled out
Link text that is not underlined, except on hover or focus, and which has a contrast ratio of 3.5:1 against the surrounding text
Images of text that appear in a logo

source: WCAG Success Criterion 1.4.12 Text Spacing

question.instruction: Under WCAG 2.1, which of the following would NOT violate conformance level A or AA success criteria?

options.text: Content that, when the user increases the line height to 1.5 times the font size, becomes unreadable
A fixed-width column of English language text that has more than 80 characters or glyphs per line
Text in a paragraph element that when magnified 200% becomes obscured by another element on the page

Content that requires the user to scroll in two dimensions to access information, when accessed on a device with a viewport width of 320 CSS pixels, except when that content requires two-dimensional layout for meaning (as with tables)

source: WCAG Success Criterion 2.5.3 Label in Name

question.instruction: Excerpts of stories appear on a page, with links after each excerpt that have the visible text "More".  However, for each of these links, the aria-label attribute has been set to "Read [title of the story]". Which users would be most likely to be inconvenienced by this pattern?

options.text: Users of screen magnification software
Users of speech recognition and control software
Users of on-screen keyboards
Nobody would experience a barrier, because this provides a unique name for each link

source: WCAG Success Criterion 1.4.13 Content on Hover or Focus

question.instruction: When a user hovers over a button (but not when it receives keyboard focus), text appears beside it.  When the mouse cursor leaves the button, the text's display property is set to none, making it disappear.  Which users would be least likely to experience a barrier from this pattern?

options.text: Users of screen reading software and those who prefer to use the keyboard
Users of screen magnification software and touch screen devices
Users of voice control software
People with dyscalculia and auditory processing disorders

source: Source: Understanding Success Criterion 4.1.3: Status Messages

question.instruction: Which of the following is NOT considered a "status message" according to WCAG 2.1?

options.text: When an error message is displayed in a dialog
An application displays a progressbar to indicate the status of an upgrade. The element is assigned a suitable role. The screen reader provides intermittent announcements of the progress.
After a user presses an Add to Shopping Cart button, a section of content near the Shopping Cart icon adds the text "5 items". A screen reader announces "Five items" or "Shopping cart, five items".
After a user activates a process, an icon symbolizing 'busy' appears on the screen. The screen reader announces "application busy".

source:
• WCAG Success Criterion 2.1.4 Character Key Shortcuts
  • WCAG Success Criterion 2.5.1 Pointer Gestures

question.instruction: Hakeem uses a web app which requires him to draw a circle around items with the pointer to select them. He has trouble doing this because he has poor fine motor control. Of the following strategies for reworking this pattern, which would allow the largest range of users to meet the goal of selecting multiple items?

options.text: Let the user click on each item to select it, making sure each item can receive keyboard focus.
Allow for the use of single character key shortcuts that cannot be changed to select items.
Use the WebSpeech API to allow users to select items by saying "click [item name]"
Allow multipoint gestures to select items

source: WCAG 2.1: Comparison with WCAG 2.0

question.instruction: Which of the following is NOT a main area of focus for WCAG 2.1?

options.text: mobile technology
augmented reality
low vision
cognitive disabilities

source: 0.5.1 New Features in WCAG 2.1

question.instruction: Which of the following has changed between WCAG 2.0 and 2.1?  Select all that apply.

options.text: Some success criteria were removed.
Some success criteria were added.
Explicit guidance was added indicating that different presentation triggered by responsive breakpoints must also be considered in determining the conformance of the page as a whole.
Definitions relating to new success criteria were added.

source: WCAG Success Criterion 2.1.4 Character Key Shortcuts

question.instruction:
If a keyboard shortcut is implemented in content using only letter (including upper- and lower-case letters), punctuation, number, or symbol characters, how can you ensure accessibility requirements are met for such shortcuts? 

Select all that apply.

options.text: A mechanism is available to turn the shortcut off.
A mechanism is available to remap the shortcut to use one or more non-printable keyboard characters (e.g. Ctrl, Alt, etc).
The keyboard shortcut for a user interface component is only active when the mouse pointer is over that component.
The keyboard shortcut for a user interface component is only active when that component has focus.
